paragraphs: Petition of A. L. Harrington and Others to U.S. Congress, [28 February 1849]1

U.S. HouseJournal. 1849. 30th Cong., 2nd sess., 567; Michael Burlingame,Abraham Lincoln: A Life(Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 2008), 1:284; “An Act for the Release

footnotes.text:
1A. L. Harrington wrote and signed the petition. Abraham Lincoln penned two instances
                  of docketing on the back page, and signed one. Lincoln presented the petition in the
                  House of Representatives on February 28, 1849, and the House referred it to the Committee
                  for the District of Columbia. Slavery was a frequent contentious topic of debate in
                  the Thirtieth Congress, although the debate did not result in any major legislation.
                  In January 1849, Lincoln himself entered the debate, introducing anamendmentto a resolution on  slavery in the District which would have abolished slavery with
                  compensation to the owners.  Slavery remained legal until 1862, when Congress passed
                  an act emancipating slaves in the District. President Lincoln signed the bill into
                  law on April 16, 1862.U.S. HouseJournal. 1849. 30th Cong., 2nd sess., 567; Michael Burlingame,Abraham Lincoln: A Life(Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 2008), 1:284; “An Act for the Release
                     of certain Persons held to Service or Labor in the
                     District of Columbia,” 16 April 1862,Statutes at Large of the United States12 (1863):376-78.
3Lincoln wrote the stricken docketing and signed his name.
